item.title: Best Spring Crops in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar, Ranked
item.description:
There are four seasons in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar : Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter. At the start of the game, the farmer arrives in Zephyr town at the beginning of Spring, and you only have a few options for early seeds to get in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar .

But once you go to your first Bazaar and have some G in hand, you can purchase several special seeds from Miguel's Bazaar stall, which significantly expand your Spring crop options. Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players can use this guide to learn the five best crops for Spring, including details on how to get seeds for each crop, how long each takes to grow, the cost of seeds, and the value of produce.

5 Rice

Long Grow Time, But Useful For Recipes

  • Days to Grow Rice : 11
  • Rice Seed Price : 110 G
  • Base Rice Crop Value : 70 G per
  • Rice Growing Seasons : Spring, Summer, Autumn

Even though it takes nearly half a season to grow, Rice is one of the best Spring crops Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players can get. Rice seeds yield between 4 and 5 crops when harvested, and because each Rice is worth 70 G, you're at least doubling your G invested in each plant.

The main issue with Rice seeds is how long it takes to grow, but because it yields such an enormous amount of crops, it's good to keep a few plots reserved for Rice. It's very useful for cooking as part of numerous recipes. Even if you don't want to take up space with Rice you don't plan to sell, it's good to plant a couple in case you unlock a new recipe (like Sashimi) that requires it.

Where to Get Rice Seeds in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

To get Rice seeds, you must purchase them from Miguel's special shop stall at the Bazaar during the Spring season. Each bag of Rice seeds costs 110 G.

4 Radish

Short Grow Time & Decent Profits

  • Days to Grow Radish : 5
  • Radish Seed Price : 90 G
  • Base Radish Crop Value : 50 G per
  • Radish Growing Seasons : Spring, Summer, Autumn

The humble Radish is one of the best early crops Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players can get, as well as one of the best Spring crops in the game in general. You can get Radish seeds practically from the start of the game, and each seed pack costs 90 G.

Each seed will yield between 3 and 4 Radish crops, which will give a tidy profit when sold at either the Bazaar or Miguel's shop. However, the real benefit of Radishes is how short the growing time is compared to other Spring crops.

You can grow Radishes every week to keep your Bazaar Stall stocked because it only takes 5 days to grow â€“ a huge benefit over other, longer-growing-time crops in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar .

Where to Get Radish Seeds in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

To get Radish seeds, you must purchase them from Miguel's Mercantile shop in the middle of Zephyr Town Square for 90 G each. You cannot purchase these from his Bazaar shop stall.

3 Strawberry

Big Profit Potential, But Only Grows In Spring

  • Days to Grow Strawberry : 8
  • Strawberry Seed Price : 180 G
  • Base Strawberry Crop Value : 120 G per
  • Strawberry Growing Seasons : Spring only

Strawberries are one of the best Spring crops Story of Seasons players can get, but there is a small catch. It takes 8 days to grow â€“ lower than most of the other best Spring seeds â€“ but it only drops between 2 and 3 crops, costs 180 G per seed pack, and can only grow in the Spring.

However, the profit margins on Strawberries are very high. At an average of 2.5x crops per seed, you'll generate about 300 G from each plant, which is a tidy 120 G profit over the 180 G seed price.

Load up on Strawberry Seeds during the first year's Spring Grand Bazaar events, then save them for the second year Spring season, when you can generate a ton of profit with these well-liked crops.

Where to Get Strawberry Seeds in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

To get Strawberry seeds, you must purchase them from Miguel's special shop stall at the Bazaar during the Spring season. Each bag of Strawberry seeds costs 180 G.

2 Soybean

Very Profitable & Relatively Cheap

  • Days to Grow Soybean : 9
  • Soybean Seed Price : 100 G
  • Base Soybean Crop Value : 65 G per
  • Soybean Growing Seasons : Spring, Summer, Autumn

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar , Soybeans are one of the best seeds to plant in Spring because of the low initial cost and decent profit you can generate thanks to their high yield. Each Soybean is worth 65 G base, and because each Soybean harvest drops between 4 and 5 crops, you'll more than double your investment with careful planning.

Soybeans are also used in a variety of recipes, like Edamame, but not as many as Wheat or Rice. If you have extra space and want to add some variety to your stall without losing out too much on the profits of the best Spring crop (Wheat), Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players should save a few spots for Soybeans in the Spring.

Where to Get Soybean Seeds in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

To get Soybean seeds, you must purchase them from Miguel's special shop stall at the Bazaar during the Spring season. Each bag of Soybean seeds costs 100 G.

1 Wheat

The Overall Best Spring Crop In Grand Bazaar

  • Days to Grow Wheat : 9
  • Wheat Seed Price : 110 G
  • Base Wheat Crop Value : 75 G per
  • Wheat Growing Seasons : Spring, Summer, Autumn

Wheat is the best Spring crop in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar because of both the enormous amount of profit it can create and its usefulness as a recipe ingredient. Wheat seeds cost 110 G, which is relatively affordable by the time you unlock Wheat to plant, usually before the Flower Festival starts.

But because it drops between 4 and 5 crops with each harvest, and each crop is worth 75 G, each Wheat seed you plant will yield nearly triple the G that you spent on seeds.

Where to Get Wheat Seeds in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

To get Wheat seeds, you must purchase them from Miguel's special shop stall at the Bazaar during the Spring season. Each bag of Wheat seeds costs 110 G.

item.title: Story of Seasons: All Romanceable Characters
item.description:
Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar is a remake of the classic life-farming simulator game Harvest Moon: Grand Bazaar for the Nintendo DS. Though much of the game's systems, locations, and characters remain intact, many go by new names.

In total, there are 12 people you can date in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar : 6 Bachelors, and 6 Bachelorettes. This guide offers an overview of each character to help players decide who to romance in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar . Choose wisely, as you may eventually have a child with your chosen marriage candidate!

Jules

A Polite & Classy Teacher

"I am a teacher, after all. I'd like to think I'm a decent judge of character."

    • Jules' Birthday : Autumn 20
    • Jules' Likes : Fragrances
    • Jules' Dislikes : Sweets

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar , Jules is the classy, purple long-tailed coat-wearing teacher of the town. The older brother of Derek, you must befriend both Jules and Derek to progress through their friendship heart events.

Derek

An Optimistic & Charming Waiter

"I know you're keepin' busy with all the farm work, but you gotta stop by for a break every now and then!"

    • Derek's Birthday : Summer 12
    • Derek's Likes : Insects
    • Derek's Dislikes : Salads

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar , Derek is the younger brother of Jules and a waiter at the local cafe. He's much more energetic than Jules and has a childlike optimism. To successfully progress Derek's friendship heart events, you must befriend Jules as well.

Lloyd

A Merchant Who's Nicer Than He Seems

"Gotta say, I couldn't believe you'd willingly take on a tough gig like that. You don't seem the type. No offense."

    • Lloyd's Birthday : Autumn 3
    • Lloyd's Likes : Elaborate Meals
    • Lloyd's Dislikes : Quick Bites

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar , Lloyd introduces himself a few days into the game and gives the Hatchet to the farmer. A bit of a standoffish fellow, you can break through Lloyd's calm exterior and learn more about the mysterious merchant via his uniquely revealing Heart events.

Gabriel

Zephyr Town's Local Artist

"Feels like I could sit here and sketch the place forever, y'know?"

    • Gabriel's Birthday : Winter 28
    • Gabriel's Likes : Sweets
    • Gabriel's Dislikes : Pickled Foods

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar , Gabriel â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹is the local artist who seems to have no end to his creative pursuits. Go into his house and you'll see paintings, sculptures, and other in-progress works of art. If you want a partner with a painter's perspective, build up your relationship with Gabriel.

Samir

A Mysterious Traveler

"...I'm Samir. Good to meet you."

    • Samir's Birthday : Winter 26
    • Samir's Likes : Home-Cooked Foods
    • Samir's Dislikes : Elaborate Meals

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹, Samir is a very enigmatic traveler who arrives in Zephyr Town after you complete some specific requirements. Samir's backstory is shrouded in mystery, and if you choose to build up your relationship with him, you'll uncover the mystical truths behind this white-haired, soft-spoken fellow.

To unlock Samir, Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players must reach Bazaar Rank 4. This requires the town to have a total of seven stalls in the Grand Bazaar and sell at least 200,000 G worth of goods.

Arata

A Friendly Martial Artist

"Just eat, sleep, and train up in that fresh mountain air. That's your one-way ticket to big gains!"

    • Arata's Birthday : Winter 17
    • Arata's Likes : Hearty Meals
    • Arata's Dislikes : Sour Foods

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹, Arata â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹is a burly mountain man who lives in the wilderness as he builds his strength. He typically shows up in Zephyr Town for the first time (at least since the Farmer arrives) after the first Grand Bazaar day. Arata can almost always be found in the Mountains, an area that opens up once he arrives to town.

To unlock Arata, Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players must reach Bazaar Rank 2. This requires the town to have a total of two stalls in the Grand Bazaar and sell at least 1,000 G worth of goods.

Sophie

The Mayor's Delightful Daughter

"Nothing brightens up the day more than a warm greeting from someone else, don't you think?"

    • Sophie's Birthday : Spring 16
    • Sophie's Likes : Refreshing Foods
    • Sophie's Dislikes : Spicy Foods

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹, Sophie is the red-haired, blue dress-wearing daughter of the Mayor. She introduces herself to the farmer soon after you arrive in Zephyr Town, and can almost always be found either inside the Mayor's house or strolling near the town square.

June

A Shy Artisan With Red Eyes

"Talking to people is just...hard, okay? So could you leave me alone already?"

    • June's Birthday : Winter 12
    • June's Likes : Dessert Foods, Tea
    • June's Dislikes : Fish

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹, June â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹starts off as a shy, standoffish girl who is new to town â€“ just like the player character. As you progress through her friendship heart events, Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players will help her break out of her shell and learn more about the gentle soul beneath her hard exterior.

Freya

A City Girl Who Stops By The Cafe At Night

"It's nice to have a career you're passionate about, don't you think?"

    • Freya's Birthday : Autumn 25
    • Freya's Likes : Beautiful Things
    • Freya's Dislikes : Pickled Foods

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar, Freya is a tall, blonde, sharp-eyed city girl who only appears in town during specific times of the day. She always walks through Zephyr town on her way home from work in the city, and you can catch her en route to the Cafe in the afternoon (or at the Cafe in the evening).

Maple

A Maid At The Hotel

"Oh, shoot...! I still have more cleaning to do!"

    • Maple's Birthday : Autumn 14
    • Maple's Likes : Sweets
    • Maple's Dislikes : Spicy Foods

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹, Maple â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹is a maid who works at the Hotel on the top-right side of town. Most of the time, you can find her working or sitting in her quarters within the Hotel, and though she might seem a bit frantic and clumsy, she always tries her best.

Kagetsu

A Reclusive & Mystical Maiden

"I feel it best that you return to your town. Time is fleeting, after all."

    • Kagetsu's Birthday : Spring 5
    • Kagetsu's Likes : Simple Foods
    • Kagetsu's Dislikes : Elaborate Foods

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹, Kagetsu typically appears at the end of Spring or the beginning of Summer, depending on how fast you can rank up your Bazaar Rating. Wearing an elaborate princess dress, Kagetsu is a mysterious character who also calls the Mountains home, but you can only get to her by taking a portal that appears.

To unlock Kagetsu, Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players must reach Bazaar Rank 3. This requires the town to have a total of four stalls in the Grand Bazaar and sell at least 50,000 G worth of goods.

Diana

A Business-Minded Review Board Agent

"As I predicted, you will be integral to this bazaar's success."

    • Diana's Birthday : Autumn 22
    • Diana's Likes : Sweets
    • Diana's Dislikes : Greasy Foods

In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹, Diana appears the first time you rank up your Bazaar Rating, which usually occurs before the Flower Festival. The all-work-no-play, business-minded Agent of the Bazaar Review Board will stay in town after giving her assessments, but if you befriend and romance her, you'll learn more about the woman beneath all the formality.

To unlock Diana, Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar players must reach Bazaar Rank 2. This requires the town to have a total of two stalls in the Grand Bazaar and sell at least 1,000 G worth of goods.

item.title: Things A Dark Souls 3 Remaster Needs To Have
item.description:
Summary

  • A Dark Souls 3 remaster likely: prioritize seamless co-op, better PvP, and richer covenants.
  • Uncapped FPS, hitbox fixes, and clearer visuals would make combat fairer and more cinematic.
  • Add boss-rush, modernized UI/inventory, and small new features to boost replay and polish.

Among all of the requested remasters out there, FromSoftware holds some of the most sought-after revivals in all of gaming. While most of the information right now comes in the form of speculation, it seems more likely than not that the next remaster from the developer will be Dark Souls 3.

FromSoftware's track record with remasters has been pretty great so far, with Dark Souls Remastered faithfully updating the iconic title, and the Demon's Souls remake improving an already fan-favorite game. If Dark Souls 3 is next on the list, there are several changes and updates that need to be included in the remaster to help it deliver the definitive finale to a genre-defining trilogy.

Seamless Co-op

Playing Together Without Issues

FromSoftware is known for its questionable philosophy when it comes to cooperative play in its Soulslike games. Most of the time, the ability to summon other players is rooted in lore and in-world reasons, which can make the actual co-op experience suffer as a result.

Through countless mods over the past decade of Souls titles, players have been implementing seamless co-op into each game, including DS3 . To make the remaster feel more well-rounded, having an intuitive and streamlined way to help others would make working together feel more enjoyable and inviting for both new and experienced players.

Uncapped FPS

Better Performance, More Cinematic Fights

One of the biggest complaints that has plagued DS3 and many other FromSoftware games is the caps placed on in-game FPS. The reason for this is that certain systems are designed around 30 or 60 FPS gameplay, meaning that exceeding these limits can actually break the game in unexpected ways.

With a new engine or an updated design philosophy, being able to fight certain enemies like Gael or The Nameless King with an FPS count that matches their grandeur would make the experience significantly more exciting, intense, and visually appealing at the same time.

Hitbox Fixes

No More Random Deaths

In a game as complex as DS3 , one of the most important things to get right is the combat. When there are flying dragons breathing fire everywhere and aggressive enemies that strike several times in a short period, having awkward hitboxes can make combat more of a chore than a joy.

By remastering the game, certain attacks and enemies could be tweaked to make their blows line up better with what is actually shown on-screen. Some things, like area attacks and more abstract swings, can be tricky to fix, but any shifts in the right direction would greatly improve the gameplay.

Visual Clutter Improvements

Seeing Things For What They Are

Boss fights and basic enemies need two boxes ticked to make fighting them rewarding and fair: visual clarity and consistency. Sometimes, when taking on a boss in DS3 , it can be hard to actually see what on earth is going on, thanks to crazy particle or fabric effects flying all over the place and obscuring the player's view.

Adjusting how certain enemies, like the Dancer of the Boreal Valley, are animated, without changing their overall appearance, could make fighting them feel much fairer and closer to how the battles were intended to play out, where the final emotion is triumph and not frustration or exhaustion.

Boss Rush

Replaying Icons Over And Over

A long-requested feature that many Dark Souls fans have been begging for is the ability to replay certain fights or even take on a set of them in sequence, to really test their skills and show off their in-game knowledge in the purest way possible.

Sekiro did implement a boss rush feature in an update, so it is clear that FromSoftware is aware of the concept and capable of creating a fun additional way of battling iconic bosses without replaying the whole game. If this same system were to find its way into the DS3 remaster, then the replay value would skyrocket, and players would finally be able to take on their favorite bosses whenever they choose.

Better Covenants

Connections That Feel Like More Than Just Item Exchanges

The covenants in DS3 leave a lot to be desired. On paper, it's a cool feature that allows players to pledge their allegiance to a specific group that aligns with their values and goals in their current playthrough.

The problem is that the actual rewards for hunting down hidden items and completing obscure quests are rarely worth the hassle. If there were greater incentives to fully embrace certain philosophies, it could transform the game into a more comprehensive RPG that offers more than just cool environments and terrifying enemies.

Better PvP

Testing Your Skills Against The Best

Despite not receiving any real post-launch content aside from DLC packs, Dark Souls 3 still maintains a small but loyal community, and one of the driving forces for that group of people is the ability to battle others and invade worlds to cause chaos and mayhem.

However, similar to the game's co-op, PvP is riddled with issues ranging from lag to problems actually joining another player, making the process more stressful than an actual invader would be. Updating this system with a new PvP mode or a better summon system would allow the community to fight one another for longer and fully enjoy the gritty sword clashes in all their glory.

New Features

Keeping The Experience Interesting And Distinct

Although Dark Souls 3 is currently rumored to be receiving a remaster in some form, that doesn't mean it can't come with a few new features. Games like Oblivion Remastered have demonstrated that revisiting a classic game can mean more than just taking in a visual overhaul. Instead, those games choose to maintain their core DNA while incorporating a few modern features and refining some less effective systems.

DS3 could definitely benefit from a similar treatment that not only updates the graphics but also extends the changes to the gameplay systems themselves. Things like the menus, the inventory screen, and the NPCs all deserve some upgrades, whether it's minor tweaks or full-on overhauls, and all those changes combined could really make the remaster feel special for long-time fans of the series.

item.title: NBA 2K26: How to Alley Oop
item.description:
Alley-oops in NBA 2K26 are naturally one of the most popular skill moves to pull off, just as they are in real basketball. For those who aren't aware and perhaps new to NBA 2K games or the sport, an alley-oop is when one player throws up the ball toward the hoop for another to catch midair , allowing them to perform a dunk or layup . It's also possible to throw the ball off the backboard to oneself for a self alley-oop , although this is usually done to showboat.

How To Alley Oop In NBA 2K26

To perform a normal alley-oop in NBA 2K26 , it's best to control a player with a high passing skill , such as a point guard. With a teammate moving toward the basket:

  • PlayStation: Double-tap Triangle
  • Xbox: Double-tap Y

This will throw the ball toward the hoop to be caught.

Alley-oops are best on the fast break in a 2 vs 1 situation or after a pick-and-roll play.

In situations where players are only controlling the passer, that's all they will need to do. However, when controlling the whole team or the receiver , a final input is required.

Receiving The Alley-oop

When receiving an alley-oop, an icon with a button will pop up. This also has a circular timer with a white marker . Try to press the button when the timer reaches the marker .

  • PlayStation: Square
  • Xbox: X

Online and on harder difficulties, the button for receiving is random each time . On PlayStation, Square, Triangle, Circle, or Cross. On Xbox, X, Y, B, or A. This is new for NBA 2K26 .

How To Alley Oop To Self In NBA 2K26

Self alley-oops are best performed in 1-on-1 scenarios where the attacking player has a height and physicality advantage , but ideally, they should be decent at passing and athletic enough to pull off a dunk. They are also a way to showboat on wide-open fast breaks .

Self alley-oops in NBA 2K26 have different controls compared with last season's game .

Practice self alley-oops, other solo skills, and shooting in the Freeplay option under the Learn 2K tab.

To perform self alley-oops in NBA 2K26 , run toward the hoop and press the following buttons at the same time .

  • PlayStation: Square & Triangle
  • Xbox: X & Y

This should lob the ball up and off the backboard. As the player rises to catch it, a button icon will appear with a timer .

  • PlayStation: Square
  • Xbox: X

Somewhere near the bottom of the circular timer is a white marker. Players should try to press the button when the timer reaches this marker . Pressing far too early or late will fail the dunk or layup.

item.title: Flower Festival Guide In Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar
item.description:
Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar is the remake of the Nintendo DS's Harvest Moon: Grand Bazaar . It adopts most things in the Harvest Moon version, including the Flower Festival. However, unlike the original, SoS Grand Bazaar Flower Festival only lasts for two days, and also has different Friendship Point mechanics.

Flower Festival In SoS Grand Bazaar - Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

The Flower Festival in SoS Grand Bazaar is a festival where you must gift as many flowers as possible to the villagers to get the Best Neighbor award. The event lasts for around 24 hours, starting from Spring 11, 12 PM (or later if you start the festival late), until Spring 12, 12 PM . Only the flowers gifted within this timeframe count for the Flower Festival.

Even if you don't end the festival on Spring 12 at 12 PM, any flowers you gift after noon will no longer count.

How To Win The Flower Festival In SoS Grand Bazaar - Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

To win the Flower Festival in Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar , you need to get at least as much as the non-player winner. For example, in the first year, Wilbur may win with 17 flowers gifted, which means players will win if they also gift 17 flowers. Since this number may change annually, a safe estimate would be over 20 flowers .

Each villager will only take one Flower Festival gift daily, so you may need to wait until the next day if you're short on the flower gift count.

Friendship Point From The Flower Festival In SoS Grand Bazaar - Story of Seasons: Grand Bazaar

Not only for the fun and awards, but the Flower Festival is a great way to increase Friendship Point with everyone. You get +300 Friendship Points (FP) when you gift a normal flower, even if the character doesn't normally like it. For example, gifting Arata a Chamomile will earn you +300 FP thanks to the festival, even if he normally doesn't like the gift.

Gifting a flower during the Flower Festival doesn't count towards the daily gift quota , meaning you can still gift a normal gift on top of the flower. Therefore, be careful about accidentally gifting a flower to someone who doesn't normally like it.

Winning the festival will grant you +200 FP for everyone in the festival, while losing will reduce the reward to +100 FP .
